Algebra with Sympy v0.11.0
built with pdoc

algebra_with_sympy.algebraic_equation

Algebraic Equations with SymPy

These tools define relations that all high school and college students would recognize as mathematical equations. They consist of a left hand side (lhs) and a right hand side (rhs) connected by a relation operator such as "=". At present the "=" relation operator is the only option. The relation operator may not be set.

This class should not be confused with the Boolean class Equality (abbreviated Eq) which specifies that the equality of two objects is True.

This tool applies operations to both sides of the equation simultaneously, just as students are taught to do when attempting to isolate (solve for) a variable. Thus the statement Equation/b yields a new equation Equation.lhs/b = Equation.rhs/b

The intent is to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to rearrange equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this way more people can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without stumbling over missed details such as a negative sign. This mimics the capabilities available in SageMath and Maxima.

   1"""
   2Algebraic Equations with SymPy
   3==============================
   4
   5These tools define relations that all high school and college students would
   6recognize as mathematical equations. They consist of a left hand side (lhs)
   7and a right hand side (rhs) connected by a relation operator such as "=". At
   8present the "=" relation operator is the only option. The relation operator may
   9not be set.
  10
  11This class should not be confused with the Boolean class ``Equality``
  12(abbreviated ``Eq``) which specifies that the equality of two objects is
  13``True``.
  14
  15This tool applies operations to both sides of the equation simultaneously, just
  16as students are taught to do when attempting to isolate (solve for) a
  17variable. Thus the statement ``Equation/b`` yields a new equation
  18``Equation.lhs/b = Equation.rhs/b``
  19
  20The intent is to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to rearrange
  21equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this way more people
  22can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without stumbling over
  23missed details such as a negative sign. This mimics the capabilities available
  24in [SageMath](https://www.sagemath.org/) and
  25[Maxima](http://maxima.sourceforge.net/).
  26"""
  27import sys
  28
  29import sympy
  30from sympy.core.add import _unevaluated_Add
  31from sympy.core.expr import Expr
  32from sympy.core.basic import Basic
  33from sympy.core.evalf import EvalfMixin
  34from sympy.core.sympify import _sympify
  35import functools
  36from sympy import *
  37
  38
  39class algwsym_config():
  40
  41    def __init__(self):
  42        """
  43        This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of
  44        the algebra_with_sympy package.
  45
  46        Settings
  47        ========
  48        Printing
  49        --------
  50        In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a
  51        human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals
  52        sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign.
  53        `print(Eqn)` or `str(Eqn)` will return this human readable text version of
  54        the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not
  55        sympy, where `str()` is supposed to return something that can be
  56        copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in `eq1 =
  57        Eqn(a,b/c)` the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in
  58        parentheses (eg. `a = b/c    (eq1)`). Use `print(repr(Eqn))` instead of
  59        `print(Eqn)` or `repr(Eqn)` instead of `str(Eqn)` to get a code
  60        compatible version of the equation.
  61
  62        You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:
  63        * `algwsym_config.output.show_code` default is `False`.
  64        * `algwsym_config.output.human_text` default is `True`.
  65        * `algwsym_config.output.label` default is `True`.
  66
  67        In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting
  68        the `algwsym_config.output.show_code` flag. If this flag is true
  69        calls to `latex` and `str` will also print an additional line "code
  70        version: `repr(Eqn)`". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset
  71        mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted.
  72        Default is `False`.
  73
  74        A second flag `algwsym_config.output.human_text` is useful in
  75        text-based interactive environments such as command line python or
  76        ipython. If this flag is true `repr` will return `str`. Thus the human
  77        readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an
  78        expression containing an equation.
  79        Default is `True`.
  80
  81        Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython
  82        environment will show both the code version and the human readable text.
  83        These flags impact the behavior of the `print(Eqn)` statement.
  84
  85        The third flag `algwsym_config.output.label` has a default value of
  86        `True`. Setting this to `False` suppresses the labeling of an equation
  87        with its python name off to the right of the equation.
  88        """
  89        pass
  90
  91    class output():
  92
  93        def __init__(self):
  94            """This holds settings that impact output.
  95            """
  96            pass
  97
  98        @property
  99        def show_code(self):
 100            """
 101            If `True` code versions of the equation expression will be
 102            output in interactive environments. Default = `False`.
 103            """
 104            return self.show_code
 105
 106        @property
 107        def human_text(self):
 108            """
 109            If `True` the human readable equation expression will be
 110            output in text interactive environments. Default = `False`.
 111            """
 112            return self.human_text
 113
 114        @property
 115        def solve_to_list(self):
 116            """
 117            If `True` the results of a call to `solve(...)` will return a
 118            Python `list` rather than a Sympy `FiniteSet`. This recovers
 119            behavior for versions before 0.11.0.
 120
 121            Note: setting this `True` means that expressions within the
 122            returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and
 123            IPython.
 124            """
 125            return self.solve_to_list
 126
 127def __latex_override__(expr, *arg):
 128    from IPython import get_ipython
 129    show_code = False
 130    if get_ipython():
 131        algwsym_config = get_ipython().user_ns.get("algwsym_config", False)
 132    else:
 133        algwsym_config = globals()['algwsym_config']
 134    if algwsym_config:
 135        show_code = algwsym_config.output.show_code
 136    if show_code:
 137        print("Code version: " + repr(expr))
 138    return '$'+latex(expr) + '$'
 139
 140def __command_line_printing__(expr, *arg):
 141    # print('Entering __command_line_printing__')
 142    human_text = True
 143    show_code = False
 144    if algwsym_config:
 145        human_text = algwsym_config.output.human_text
 146        show_code = algwsym_config.output.show_code
 147    tempstr = ''
 148    if show_code:
 149        tempstr += "Code version: " + repr(expr) + '\n'
 150    if not human_text:
 151        return print(tempstr + repr(expr))
 152    else:
 153        return print(tempstr + str(expr))
 154
 155# Now we inject the formatting override(s)
 156from IPython import get_ipython
 157ip = get_ipython()
 158formatter = None
 159if ip:
 160    # In an environment that can display typeset latex
 161    formatter = ip.display_formatter
 162    old = formatter.formatters['text/latex'].for_type(Basic,
 163                                                      __latex_override__)
 164    # print("For type Basic overriding latex formatter = " + str(old))
 165
 166    # For the terminal based IPython
 167    if "text/latex" not in formatter.active_types:
 168        old = formatter.formatters['text/plain'].for_type(tuple,
 169                                                    __command_line_printing__)
 170        # print("For type tuple overriding plain text formatter = " + str(old))
 171        for k in sympy.__all__:
 172            if k in globals() and not "Printer" in k:
 173                if isinstance(globals()[k], type):
 174                    old = formatter.formatters['text/plain'].\
 175                        for_type(globals()[k], __command_line_printing__)
 176                    # print("For type "+str(k)+
 177                    # " overriding plain text formatter = " + str(old))
 178else:
 179    # command line
 180    # print("Overiding command line printing of python.")
 181    sys.displayhook = __command_line_printing__
 182
 183class Equation(Basic, EvalfMixin):
 184    """
 185    This class defines an equation with a left-hand-side (tlhs) and a right-
 186    hand-side (rhs) connected by the "=" operator (e.g. `p*V = n*R*T`).
 187
 188    Explanation
 189    ===========
 190    This class defines relations that all high school and college students
 191    would recognize as mathematical equations. At present only the "=" relation
 192    operator is recognized.
 193
 194    This class is intended to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to
 195    rearrange equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this
 196    way more people can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without
 197    stumbling over missed details such as a negative sign.
 198
 199    Create an equation with the call ``Equation(lhs,rhs)``, where ``lhs`` and
 200    ``rhs`` are any valid Sympy expression. ``Eqn(...)`` is a synonym for
 201    ``Equation(...)``.
 202
 203    Parameters
 204    ==========
 205    lhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
 206    rhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
 207    kwargs:
 208
 209    Examples
 210    ========
 211    NOTE: All the examples below are in vanilla python. You can get human
 212    readable eqautions "lhs = rhs" in vanilla python by adjusting the settings
 213    in `algwsym_config` (see it's documentation). Output is human readable by
 214    default in IPython and Jupyter environments.
 215    >>> from algebra_with_sympy import *
 216    >>> a, b, c, x = var('a b c x')
 217    >>> Equation(a,b/c)
 218    Equation(a, b/c)
 219    >>> t=Eqn(a,b/c)
 220    >>> t
 221    Equation(a, b/c)
 222    >>> t*c
 223    Equation(a*c, b)
 224    >>> c*t
 225    Equation(a*c, b)
 226    >>> exp(t)
 227    Equation(exp(a), exp(b/c))
 228    >>> exp(log(t))
 229    Equation(a, b/c)
 230
 231    Simplification and Expansion
 232    >>> f = Eqn(x**2 - 1, c)
 233    >>> f
 234    Equation(x**2 - 1, c)
 235    >>> f/(x+1)
 236    Equation((x**2 - 1)/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
 237    >>> (f/(x+1)).simplify()
 238    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
 239    >>> simplify(f/(x+1))
 240    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
 241    >>> (f/(x+1)).expand()
 242    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
 243    >>> expand(f/(x+1))
 244    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
 245    >>> factor(f)
 246    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
 247    >>> f.factor()
 248    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
 249    >>> f2 = f+a*x**2+b*x +c
 250    >>> f2
 251    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c + x**2 - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
 252    >>> collect(f2,x)
 253    Equation(b*x + c + x**2*(a + 1) - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
 254
 255    Apply operation to only one side
 256    >>> poly = Eqn(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 257    >>> poly.applyrhs(factor,x)
 258    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(c + x**2*(a + b)))
 259    >>> poly.applylhs(factor)
 260    Equation(x*(a*x + b + c*x), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 261    >>> poly.applylhs(collect,x)
 262    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 263
 264    ``.apply...`` also works with user defined python functions
 265    >>> def addsquare(eqn):
 266    ...     return eqn+eqn**2
 267    ...
 268    >>> t.apply(addsquare)
 269    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 270    >>> t.applyrhs(addsquare)
 271    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 272    >>> t.apply(addsquare, side = 'rhs')
 273    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 274    >>> t.applylhs(addsquare)
 275    Equation(a**2 + a, b/c)
 276    >>> addsquare(t)
 277    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 278
 279    Inaddition to ``.apply...`` there is also the less general ``.do``,
 280    ``.dolhs``, ``.dorhs``, which only works for operations defined on the
 281    ``Expr`` class (e.g.``.collect(), .factor(), .expand()``, etc...).
 282    >>> poly.dolhs.collect(x)
 283    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 284    >>> poly.dorhs.collect(x)
 285    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, c*x + x**3*(a + b))
 286    >>> poly.do.collect(x)
 287    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), c*x + x**3*(a + b))
 288    >>> poly.dorhs.factor()
 289    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(a*x**2 + b*x**2 + c))
 290
 291    ``poly.do.exp()`` or other sympy math functions will raise an error.
 292
 293    Rearranging an equation (simple example made complicated as illustration)
 294    >>> p, V, n, R, T = var('p V n R T')
 295    >>> eq1=Eqn(p*V,n*R*T)
 296    >>> eq1
 297    Equation(V*p, R*T*n)
 298    >>> eq2 =eq1/V
 299    >>> eq2
 300    Equation(p, R*T*n/V)
 301    >>> eq3 = eq2/R/T
 302    >>> eq3
 303    Equation(p/(R*T), n/V)
 304    >>> eq4 = eq3*R/p
 305    >>> eq4
 306    Equation(1/T, R*n/(V*p))
 307    >>> 1/eq4
 308    Equation(T, V*p/(R*n))
 309    >>> eq5 = 1/eq4 - T
 310    >>> eq5
 311    Equation(0, -T + V*p/(R*n))
 312
 313    Substitution (#'s and units)
 314    >>> L, atm, mol, K = var('L atm mol K', positive=True, real=True) # units
 315    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L})
 316    Equation(p, 0.9334325*atm)
 317    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L}).evalf(4)
 318    Equation(p, 0.9334*atm)
 319
 320    Substituting an equation into another equation:
 321    >>> P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2 = symbols("P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2")
 322    >>> eq1 = Eqn(P, P1 + P2)
 323    >>> eq2 = Eqn(P1 / (A1 * E1), P2 / (A2 * E2))
 324    >>> P1_val = (eq1 - P2).swap
 325    >>> P1_val
 326    Equation(P1, P - P2)
 327    >>> eq2 = eq2.subs(P1_val)
 328    >>> eq2
 329    Equation((P - P2)/(A1*E1), P2/(A2*E2))
 330    >>> P2_val = solve(eq2.subs(P1_val), P2).args[0]
 331    >>> P2_val
 332    Equation(P2, A2*E2*P/(A1*E1 + A2*E2))
 333
 334    Combining equations (Math with equations: lhs with lhs and rhs with rhs)
 335    >>> q = Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
 336    >>> q
 337    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
 338    >>> t
 339    Equation(a, b/c)
 340    >>> q+t
 341    Equation(a*c + a, b/c + b/c**2)
 342    >>> q/t
 343    Equation(c, 1/c)
 344    >>> t**q
 345    Equation(a**(a*c), (b/c)**(b/c**2))
 346
 347    Utility operations
 348    >>> t.reversed
 349    Equation(b/c, a)
 350    >>> t.swap
 351    Equation(b/c, a)
 352    >>> t.lhs
 353    a
 354    >>> t.rhs
 355    b/c
 356    >>> t.as_Boolean()
 357    Eq(a, b/c)
 358
 359    `.check()` convenience method for `.as_Boolean().simplify()`
 360    >>> from sympy import I, pi
 361    >>> Equation(pi*(I+2), pi*I+2*pi).check()
 362    True
 363    >>> Eqn(a,a+1).check()
 364    False
 365
 366    Differentiation
 367    Differentiation is applied to both sides if the wrt variable appears on
 368    both sides.
 369    >>> q=Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
 370    >>> q
 371    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
 372    >>> diff(q,b)
 373    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b), c**(-2))
 374    >>> diff(q,c)
 375    Equation(a, -2*b/c**3)
 376    >>> diff(log(q),b)
 377    Equation(Derivative(log(a*c), b), 1/b)
 378    >>> diff(q,c,2)
 379    Equation(Derivative(a, c), 6*b/c**4)
 380
 381    If you specify multiple differentiation all at once the assumption
 382    is order of differentiation matters and the lhs will not be
 383    evaluated.
 384    >>> diff(q,c,b)
 385    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
 386
 387    To overcome this specify the order of operations.
 388    >>> diff(diff(q,c),b)
 389    Equation(Derivative(a, b), -2/c**3)
 390
 391    But the reverse order returns an unevaulated lhs (a may depend on b).
 392    >>> diff(diff(q,b),c)
 393    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
 394
 395    Integration can only be performed on one side at a time.
 396    >>> q=Eqn(a*c,b/c)
 397    >>> integrate(q,b,side='rhs')
 398    b**2/(2*c)
 399    >>> integrate(q,b,side='lhs')
 400    a*b*c
 401
 402    Make a pretty statement of integration from an equation
 403    >>> Eqn(Integral(q.lhs,b),integrate(q,b,side='rhs'))
 404    Equation(Integral(a*c, b), b**2/(2*c))
 405
 406    Integration of each side with respect to different variables
 407    >>> q.dorhs.integrate(b).dolhs.integrate(a)
 408    Equation(a**2*c/2, b**2/(2*c))
 409
 410    Automatic solutions using sympy solvers. THIS IS EXPERIMENTAL. Please
 411    report issues at https://github.com/gutow/Algebra_with_Sympy/issues.
 412    >>> tosolv = Eqn(a - b, c/a)
 413    >>> solve(tosolv,a)
 414    FiniteSet(Equation(a, b/2 - sqrt(b**2 + 4*c)/2), Equation(a, b/2 + sqrt(b**2 + 4*c)/2))
 415    >>> solve(tosolv, b)
 416    FiniteSet(Equation(b, (a**2 - c)/a))
 417    >>> solve(tosolv, c)
 418    FiniteSet(Equation(c, a**2 - a*b))
 419    """
 420
 421    def __new__(cls, lhs, rhs, **kwargs):
 422        lhs = _sympify(lhs)
 423        rhs = _sympify(rhs)
 424        if not isinstance(lhs, Expr) or not isinstance(rhs, Expr):
 425            raise TypeError('lhs and rhs must be valid sympy expressions.')
 426        return super().__new__(cls, lhs, rhs)
 427
 428    def _get_eqn_name(self):
 429        """
 430        Tries to find the python string name that refers to the equation. In
 431        IPython environments (IPython, Jupyter, etc...) looks in the user_ns.
 432        If not in an IPython environment looks in __main__.
 433        :return: string value if found or empty string.
 434        """
 435        human_text = algwsym_config.output.human_text
 436        algwsym_config.output.human_text=False
 437        import __main__ as shell
 438        for k in dir(shell):
 439            item = getattr(shell,k)
 440            if isinstance(item,Equation):
 441                if item.__repr__()==self.__repr__() and not \
 442                        k.startswith('_'):
 443                    algwsym_config.output.human_text=human_text
 444                    return k
 445        algwsym_config.output.human_text = human_text
 446        return ''
 447
 448    @property
 449    def lhs(self):
 450        """
 451        Returns the lhs of the equation.
 452        """
 453        return self.args[0]
 454
 455    @property
 456    def rhs(self):
 457        """
 458        Returns the rhs of the equation.
 459        """
 460        return self.args[1]
 461
 462    def as_Boolean(self):
 463        """
 464        Converts the equation to an Equality.
 465        """
 466        return Equality(self.lhs, self.rhs)
 467
 468    def check(self, **kwargs):
 469        """
 470        Forces simplification and casts as `Equality` to check validity.
 471        Parameters
 472        ----------
 473        kwargs any appropriate for `Equality`.
 474
 475        Returns
 476        -------
 477        True, False or an unevaluated `Equality` if truth cannot be determined.
 478        """
 479        return Equality(self.lhs, self.rhs, **kwargs).simplify()
 480
 481    @property
 482    def reversed(self):
 483        """
 484        Swaps the lhs and the rhs.
 485        """
 486        return Equation(self.rhs, self.lhs)
 487
 488    @property
 489    def swap(self):
 490        """
 491        Synonym for `.reversed`
 492        """
 493        return self.reversed
 494
 495    def _applytoexpr(self, expr, func, *args, **kwargs):
 496        # Applies a function to an expression checking whether there
 497        # is a specialized version associated with the particular type of
 498        # expression. Errors will be raised if the function cannot be
 499        # applied to an expression.
 500        funcname = getattr(func, '__name__', None)
 501        if funcname is not None:
 502            localfunc = getattr(expr, funcname, None)
 503            if localfunc is not None:
 504                return localfunc(*args, **kwargs)
 505        return func(expr, *args, **kwargs)
 506
 507    def apply(self, func, *args, side='both', **kwargs):
 508        """
 509        Apply an operation/function/method to the equation returning the
 510        resulting equation.
 511
 512        Parameters
 513        ==========
 514
 515        func: object
 516            object to apply usually a function
 517
 518        args: as necessary for the function
 519
 520        side: 'both', 'lhs', 'rhs', optional
 521            Specifies which side of the equation the operation will be applied
 522            to. Default is 'both'.
 523
 524        kwargs: as necessary for the function
 525         """
 526        lhs = self.lhs
 527        rhs = self.rhs
 528        if side in ('both', 'lhs'):
 529            lhs = self._applytoexpr(self.lhs, func, *args, **kwargs)
 530        if side in ('both', 'rhs'):
 531            rhs = self._applytoexpr(self.rhs, func, *args, **kwargs)
 532        return Equation(lhs, rhs)
 533
 534    def applylhs(self, func, *args, **kwargs):
 535        """
 536        If lhs side of the equation has a defined subfunction (attribute) of
 537        name ``func``, that will be applied instead of the global function.
 538        The operation is applied to only the lhs.
 539        """
 540        return self.apply(func, *args, **kwargs, side='lhs')
 541
 542    def applyrhs(self, func, *args, **kwargs):
 543        """
 544        If rhs side of the equation has a defined subfunction (attribute) of
 545        name ``func``, that will be applied instead of the global function.
 546        The operation is applied to only the rhs.
 547        """
 548        return self.apply(func, *args, **kwargs, side='rhs')
 549
 550    class _sides:
 551        """
 552        Helper class for the `.do.`, `.dolhs.`, `.dorhs.` syntax for applying
 553        submethods of expressions.
 554        """
 555
 556        def __init__(self, eqn, side='both'):
 557            self.eqn = eqn
 558            self.side = side
 559
 560        def __getattr__(self, name):
 561            func = None
 562            if self.side in ('rhs', 'both'):
 563                func = getattr(self.eqn.rhs, name, None)
 564            else:
 565                func = getattr(self.eqn.lhs, name, None)
 566            if func is None:
 567                raise AttributeError('Expressions in the equation have no '
 568                                     'attribute `' + str(
 569                    name) + '`. Try `.apply('
 570                                     + str(name) + ', *args)` or '
 571                                                   'pass the equation as a parameter to `'
 572                                     + str(name) + '()`.')
 573            return functools.partial(self.eqn.apply, func, side=self.side)
 574
 575    @property
 576    def do(self):
 577        return self._sides(self, side='both')
 578
 579    @property
 580    def dolhs(self):
 581        return self._sides(self, side='lhs')
 582
 583    @property
 584    def dorhs(self):
 585        return self._sides(self, side='rhs')
 586    
 587    def _eval_rewrite(self, rule, args, **kwargs):
 588        """Return Equation(L, R) as Equation(L - R, 0) or as L - R.
 589
 590        Parameters
 591        ==========
 592
 593        evaluate : bool, optional
 594            Control the evaluation of the result. If `evaluate=None` then
 595            terms in L and R will not cancel but they will be listed in
 596            canonical order; otherwise non-canonical args will be returned.
 597            Default to True.
 598        
 599        eqn : bool, optional
 600            Control the returned type. If `eqn=True`, then Equation(L - R, 0)
 601            is returned. Otherwise, the L - R symbolic expression is returned.
 602            Default to True.
 603
 604        Examples
 605        ========
 606        >>> from sympy import Add
 607        >>> from sympy.abc import b, x
 608        >>> from algebra_with_sympy import Equation
 609        >>> eq = Equation(x + b, x - b)
 610        >>> eq.rewrite(Add)
 611        Equation(2*b, 0)
 612        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, evaluate=None).lhs.args
 613        (b, b, x, -x)
 614        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, evaluate=False).lhs.args
 615        (b, x, b, -x)
 616        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, eqn=False)
 617        2*b
 618        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, eqn=False, evaluate=False).args
 619        (b, x, b, -x)
 620        """
 621        if rule == Add:
 622            # NOTE: the code about `evaluate` is very similar to
 623            # sympy.core.relational.Equality._eval_rewrite_as_Add
 624            eqn = kwargs.pop("eqn", True)
 625            evaluate = kwargs.get('evaluate', True)
 626            L, R = args
 627            if evaluate:
 628                # allow cancellation of args
 629                expr = L - R
 630            else:
 631                args = Add.make_args(L) + Add.make_args(-R)
 632                if evaluate is None:
 633                    # no cancellation, but canonical
 634                    expr = _unevaluated_Add(*args)
 635                else:
 636                    # no cancellation, not canonical
 637                    expr = Add._from_args(args)
 638            if eqn:
 639                return self.func(expr, 0)
 640            return expr
 641
 642    def subs(self, *args, **kwargs):
 643        """Substitutes old for new in an equation after sympifying args.
 644    
 645        `args` is either:
 646
 647        * one or more arguments of type `Equation(old, new)`.
 648        * two arguments, e.g. foo.subs(old, new)
 649        * one iterable argument, e.g. foo.subs(iterable). The iterable may be:
 650
 651            - an iterable container with (old, new) pairs. In this case the
 652              replacements are processed in the order given with successive
 653              patterns possibly affecting replacements already made.
 654            - a dict or set whose key/value items correspond to old/new pairs.
 655              In this case the old/new pairs will be sorted by op count and in
 656              case of a tie, by number of args and the default_sort_key. The
 657              resulting sorted list is then processed as an iterable container
 658              (see previous).
 659        
 660        If the keyword ``simultaneous`` is True, the subexpressions will not be
 661        evaluated until all the substitutions have been made.
 662
 663        Please, read ``help(Expr.subs)`` for more examples.
 664
 665        Examples
 666        ========
 667
 668        >>> from sympy.abc import a, b, c, x
 669        >>> from algebra_with_sympy import Equation
 670        >>> eq = Equation(x + a, b * c)
 671
 672        Substitute a single value:
 673
 674        >>> eq.subs(b, 4)
 675        Equation(a + x, 4*c)
 676
 677        Substitute a multiple values:
 678
 679        >>> eq.subs([(a, 2), (b, 4)])
 680        Equation(x + 2, 4*c)
 681        >>> eq.subs({a: 2, b: 4})
 682        Equation(x + 2, 4*c)
 683
 684        Substitute an equation into another equation:
 685
 686        >>> eq2 = Equation(x + a, 4)
 687        >>> eq.subs(eq2)
 688        Equation(4, b*c)
 689
 690        Substitute multiple equations into another equation:
 691
 692        >>> eq1 = Equation(x + a + b + c, x * a * b * c)
 693        >>> eq2 = Equation(x + a, 4)
 694        >>> eq3 = Equation(b, 5)
 695        >>> eq1.subs(eq2, eq3)
 696        Equation(c + 9, 5*a*c*x)
 697
 698        """
 699        new_args = args
 700        if all(isinstance(a, self.func) for a in args):
 701            new_args = [{a.args[0]: a.args[1] for a in args}]
 702        elif (len(args) == 1) and all(isinstance(a, self.func) for a in
 703                                      args[0]):
 704            raise TypeError("You passed into `subs` a list of elements of "
 705                "type `Equation`, but this is not supported. Please, consider "
 706                "unpacking the list with `.subs(*eq_list)` or select your "
 707                "equations from the list and use `.subs(eq_list[0], eq_list["
 708                "2], ...)`.")
 709        elif any(isinstance(a, self.func) for a in args):
 710            raise ValueError("`args` contains one or more Equation and some "
 711                "other data type. This mode of operation is not supported. "
 712                "Please, read `subs` documentation to understand how to "
 713                "use it.")
 714        return super().subs(*new_args, **kwargs)
 715
 716    #####
 717    # Overrides of binary math operations
 718    #####
 719
 720    @classmethod
 721    def _binary_op(cls, a, b, opfunc_ab):
 722        if isinstance(a, Equation) and not isinstance(b, Equation):
 723            return Equation(opfunc_ab(a.lhs, b), opfunc_ab(a.rhs, b))
 724        elif isinstance(b, Equation) and not isinstance(a, Equation):
 725            return Equation(opfunc_ab(a, b.lhs), opfunc_ab(a, b.rhs))
 726        elif isinstance(a, Equation) and isinstance(b, Equation):
 727            return Equation(opfunc_ab(a.lhs, b.lhs), opfunc_ab(a.rhs, b.rhs))
 728        else:
 729            return NotImplemented
 730
 731    def __add__(self, other):
 732        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a + b)
 733
 734    def __radd__(self, other):
 735        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a + b)
 736
 737    def __mul__(self, other):
 738        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a * b)
 739
 740    def __rmul__(self, other):
 741        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a * b)
 742
 743    def __sub__(self, other):
 744        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a - b)
 745
 746    def __rsub__(self, other):
 747        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a - b)
 748
 749    def __truediv__(self, other):
 750        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a / b)
 751
 752    def __rtruediv__(self, other):
 753        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a / b)
 754
 755    def __mod__(self, other):
 756        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a % b)
 757
 758    def __rmod__(self, other):
 759        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a % b)
 760
 761    def __pow__(self, other):
 762        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a ** b)
 763
 764    def __rpow__(self, other):
 765        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a ** b)
 766
 767    def _eval_power(self, other):
 768        return self.__pow__(other)
 769
 770    #####
 771    # Operation helper functions
 772    #####
 773    def expand(self, *args, **kwargs):
 774        return Equation(self.lhs.expand(*args, **kwargs), self.rhs.expand(
 775            *args, **kwargs))
 776
 777    def simplify(self, *args, **kwargs):
 778        return self._eval_simplify(*args, **kwargs)
 779
 780    def _eval_simplify(self, *args, **kwargs):
 781        return Equation(self.lhs.simplify(*args, **kwargs), self.rhs.simplify(
 782            *args, **kwargs))
 783
 784    def _eval_factor(self, *args, **kwargs):
 785        # TODO: cancel out factors common to both sides.
 786        return Equation(self.lhs.factor(*args, **kwargs), self.rhs.factor(
 787            *args, **kwargs))
 788
 789    def factor(self, *args, **kwargs):
 790        return self._eval_factor(*args, **kwargs)
 791
 792    def _eval_collect(self, *args, **kwargs):
 793        from sympy.simplify.radsimp import collect
 794        return Equation(collect(self.lhs, *args, **kwargs),
 795                        collect(self.rhs, *args, **kwargs))
 796
 797    def collect(self, *args, **kwargs):
 798        return self._eval_collect(*args, **kwargs)
 799
 800    def evalf(self, *args, **kwargs):
 801        return Equation(self.lhs.evalf(*args, **kwargs),
 802                        self.rhs.evalf(*args, **kwargs))
 803
 804    n = evalf
 805
 806    def _eval_derivative(self, *args, **kwargs):
 807        # TODO Find why diff and Derivative do not appear to pass through
 808        #  kwargs to this. Since we cannot set evaluation of lhs manually
 809        #  try to be intelligent about when to do it.
 810        from sympy.core.function import Derivative
 811        eval_lhs = False
 812        if not (isinstance(self.lhs, Derivative)):
 813            for sym in args:
 814                if sym in self.lhs.free_symbols and not (
 815                        _sympify(sym).is_number):
 816                    eval_lhs = True
 817        return Equation(self.lhs.diff(*args, **kwargs, evaluate=eval_lhs),
 818                        self.rhs.diff(*args, **kwargs))
 819
 820    def _eval_Integral(self, *args, **kwargs):
 821        side = kwargs.pop('side', None)  # Could not seem to pass values for
 822        # `evaluate` through to here.
 823        if side is None:
 824            raise ValueError('You must specify `side="lhs"` or `side="rhs"` '
 825                             'when integrating an Equation')
 826        else:
 827            try:
 828                return (getattr(self, side).integrate(*args, **kwargs))
 829            except AttributeError:
 830                raise AttributeError('`side` must equal "lhs" or "rhs".')
 831
 832    #####
 833    # Output helper functions
 834    #####
 835    def __repr__(self):
 836        repstr = 'Equation(%s, %s)' %(self.lhs.__repr__(), self.rhs.__repr__())
 837        # if algwsym_config.output.human_text:
 838        #     return self.__str__()
 839        return repstr
 840
 841    def _latex(self, printer):
 842        tempstr = ''
 843        """
 844        if algwsym_config.output.show_code and not \
 845            algwsym_config.output.human_text:
 846            print('code version: '+ self.__repr__())
 847        """
 848        tempstr += printer._print(self.lhs)
 849        tempstr += '='
 850        tempstr += printer._print(self.rhs)
 851        namestr = self._get_eqn_name()
 852        if namestr !='' and algwsym_config.output.label:
 853            tempstr += '\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,'
 854            tempstr += '(\\text{'+namestr+'})'
 855        return tempstr
 856
 857    def __str__(self):
 858        tempstr = ''
 859        # if algwsym_config.output.show_code:
 860        #     human_text = algwsym_config.output.human_text
 861        #     algwsym_config.output.human_text=False
 862        #     tempstr += '\ncode version: '+self.__repr__() +'\n'
 863        #     algwsym_config.output.human_text=human_text
 864        tempstr += str(self.lhs) + ' = ' + str(self.rhs)
 865        namestr = self._get_eqn_name()
 866        if namestr != '' and algwsym_config.output.label:
 867            tempstr += '          (' + namestr + ')'
 868        return tempstr
 869
 870
 871Eqn = Equation
 872if ip and "text/latex" not in formatter.active_types:
 873    old = formatter.formatters['text/plain'].for_type(Eqn,
 874                                                __command_line_printing__)
 875    # print("For type Equation overriding plain text formatter = " + str(old))
 876
 877def solve(f, *symbols, **flags):
 878    """
 879    Override of sympy `solve()`.
 880
 881    If passed an expression and variable(s) to solve for it behaves
 882    almost the same as normal solve with `dict = True`, except that solutions
 883    are wrapped in a FiniteSet() to guarantee that the output will be pretty
 884    printed in Jupyter like environments.
 885
 886    If passed an equation or equations it returns solutions as a
 887    `FiniteSet()` of solutions, where each solution is represented by an
 888    equation or set of equations.
 889
 890    To get a Python `list` of solutions (pre-0.11.0 behavior) rather than a
 891    `FiniteSet` issue the command `algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list = True`.
 892    This also prevents pretty-printing in IPython and Jupyter.
 893
 894    Examples
 895    --------
 896    >>> a, b, c, x, y = symbols('a b c x y', real = True)
 897    >>> import sys
 898    >>> sys.displayhook = __command_line_printing__ # set by default on normal initialization.
 899    >>> eq1 = Eqn(abs(2*x+y),3)
 900    >>> eq2 = Eqn(abs(x + 2*y),3)
 901    >>> B = solve((eq1,eq2))
 902
 903    Default human readable output on command line
 904    >>> B
 905    {{x = -3, y = 3}, {x = -1, y = -1}, {x = 1, y = 1}, {x = 3, y = -3}}
 906
 907    To get raw output turn off by setting
 908    >>> algwsym_config.output.human_text=False
 909    >>> B
 910    FiniteSet(FiniteSet(Equation(x, -3), Equation(y, 3)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, -1), Equation(y, -1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 1), Equation(y, 1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 3), Equation(y, -3)))
 911
 912    Pre-0.11.0 behavior where a python list of solutions is returned
 913    >>> algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list = True
 914    >>> solve((eq1,eq2))
 915    [[Equation(x, -3), Equation(y, 3)], [Equation(x, -1), Equation(y, -1)], [Equation(x, 1), Equation(y, 1)], [Equation(x, 3), Equation(y, -3)]]
 916    >>> algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list = False # reset to default
 917
 918    `algwsym_config.output.human_text = True` with
 919    `algwsym_config.output.how_code=True` shows both.
 920    In Jupyter-like environments `show_code=True` yields the Raw output and
 921    a typeset version. If `show_code=False` (the default) only the
 922    typeset version is shown in Jupyter.
 923    >>> algwsym_config.output.show_code=True
 924    >>> algwsym_config.output.human_text=True
 925    >>> B
 926    Code version: FiniteSet(FiniteSet(Equation(x, -3), Equation(y, 3)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, -1), Equation(y, -1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 1), Equation(y, 1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 3), Equation(y, -3)))
 927    {{x = -3, y = 3}, {x = -1, y = -1}, {x = 1, y = 1}, {x = 3, y = -3}}
 928    """
 929    from sympy.solvers.solvers import solve
 930    from sympy.sets.sets import FiniteSet
 931    from IPython.display import display
 932    newf =[]
 933    solns = []
 934    displaysolns = []
 935    contains_eqn = False
 936    if hasattr(f,'__iter__'):
 937        for k in f:
 938            if isinstance(k, Equation):
 939                newf.append(k.lhs-k.rhs)
 940                contains_eqn = True
 941            else:
 942                newf.append(k)
 943    else:
 944        if isinstance(f, Equation):
 945            newf.append(f.lhs - f.rhs)
 946            contains_eqn = True
 947        else:
 948            newf.append(f)
 949    flags['dict'] = True
 950    result = solve(newf, *symbols, **flags)
 951    if contains_eqn:
 952        if len(result[0]) == 1:
 953            for k in result:
 954                for key in k.keys():
 955                    val = k[key]
 956                    tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
 957                    solns.append(tempeqn)
 958        else:
 959            for k in result:
 960                solnset = []
 961                for key in k.keys():
 962                    val = k[key]
 963                    tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
 964                    solnset.append(tempeqn)
 965                if not algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list:
 966                    solnset = FiniteSet(*solnset)
 967                solns.append(solnset)
 968    else:
 969        solns = result
 970    if algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list:
 971        return list(solns)
 972    else:
 973        return FiniteSet(*solns)
 974
 975def solveset(f, symbols, domain=sympy.Complexes):
 976    """
 977    Very experimental override of sympy solveset, which we hope will replace
 978    solve. Much is not working. It is not clear how to input a system of
 979    equations unless you directly select `linsolve`, etc...
 980    """
 981    from sympy.solvers import solveset as solve
 982    from IPython.display import display
 983    newf = []
 984    solns = []
 985    displaysolns = []
 986    contains_eqn = False
 987    if hasattr(f, '__iter__'):
 988        for k in f:
 989            if isinstance(k, Equation):
 990                newf.append(k.lhs - k.rhs)
 991                contains_eqn = True
 992            else:
 993                newf.append(k)
 994    else:
 995        if isinstance(f, Equation):
 996            newf.append(f.lhs - f.rhs)
 997            contains_eqn = True
 998        else:
 999            newf.append(f)
1000    result = solve(*newf, symbols, domain=domain)
1001    # if contains_eqn:
1002    #     if len(result[0]) == 1:
1003    #         for k in result:
1004    #             for key in k.keys():
1005    #                 val = k[key]
1006    #                 tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
1007    #                 solns.append(tempeqn)
1008    #         display(*solns)
1009    #     else:
1010    #         for k in result:
1011    #             solnset = []
1012    #             displayset = []
1013    #             for key in k.keys():
1014    #                 val = k[key]
1015    #                 tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
1016    #                 solnset.append(tempeqn)
1017    #                 if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1018    #                     displayset.append(tempeqn)
1019    #             if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1020    #                 displayset.append('-----')
1021    #             solns.append(solnset)
1022    #             if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1023    #                 for k in displayset:
1024    #                     displaysolns.append(k)
1025    #         if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1026    #             display(*displaysolns)
1027    # else:
1028    solns = result
1029    return solns
1030
1031def sqrt(arg, evaluate = None):
1032    """
1033    Override of sympy convenience function `sqrt`. Simply divides equations
1034    into two sides if `arg` is an instance of `Equation`. This avoids an
1035    issue with the way sympy is delaying specialized applications of _Pow_ on
1036    objects that are not basic sympy expressions.
1037    """
1038    from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import sqrt as symsqrt
1039    if isinstance(arg, Equation):
1040        return Equation(symsqrt(arg.lhs, evaluate), symsqrt(arg.rhs, evaluate))
1041    else:
1042        return symsqrt(arg,evaluate)
1043
1044# Pick up the docstring for sqrt from sympy
1045from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import sqrt as symsqrt
1046sqrt.__doc__+=symsqrt.__doc__
1047del symsqrt
1048
1049def root(arg, n, k = 0, evaluate = None):
1050    """
1051    Override of sympy convenience function `root`. Simply divides equations
1052    into two sides if `arg`  or `n` is an instance of `Equation`. This
1053    avoids an issue with the way sympy is delaying specialized applications
1054    of _Pow_ on objects that are not basic sympy expressions.
1055    """
1056    from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import root as symroot
1057    if isinstance(arg, Equation):
1058        return Equation(symroot(arg.lhs, n, k, evaluate),
1059                        symroot(arg.rhs, n, k, evaluate))
1060    if isinstance(n, Equation):
1061        return Equation(symroot(arg, n.lhs, k, evaluate),
1062                        symroot(arg, n.rhs, k, evaluate))
1063    else:
1064        return symroot(arg, n, k, evaluate)
1065
1066# pick up the docstring for root from sympy
1067from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import root as symroot
1068root.__doc__+=symroot.__doc__
1069del symroot
1070
1071def Heaviside(arg, **kwargs):
1072    """
1073    Overide of the Heaviside function as implemented in Sympy. Get a recursion
1074    error if use the normal class extension of a function to do this.
1075
1076    """
1077    from sympy.functions.special.delta_functions import Heaviside as symHeav
1078    if isinstance(arg, Equation):
1079        return Equation(symHeav((arg.lhs), **kwargs),symHeav((arg.rhs),
1080                                                             **kwargs))
1081    else:
1082        return symHeav(arg, **kwargs)
1083# Pick up the docstring for Heaviside from Sympy.
1084from sympy.functions.special.delta_functions import Heaviside as symHeav
1085Heaviside.__doc__ += symHeav.__doc__
1086del symHeav
1087
1088def collect(expr, syms, func=None, evaluate=None, exact=False,
1089            distribute_order_term=True):
1090    """
1091    Override of sympy `collect()`.
1092    """
1093    from sympy.simplify.radsimp import collect
1094    _eval_collect = getattr(expr, '_eval_collect', None)
1095    if _eval_collect is not None:
1096        return _eval_collect(syms, func, evaluate,
1097                             exact, distribute_order_term)
1098    else:
1099        return collect(expr, syms, func, evaluate, exact,
1100                       distribute_order_term)
1101
1102class Equality(Equality):
1103    """
1104    Extension of Equality class to include the ability to convert it to an
1105    Equation.
1106    """
1107    def to_Equation(self):
1108        """
1109        Return: recasts the Equality as an Equation.
1110        """
1111        return Equation(self.lhs,self.rhs)
1112
1113    def to_Eqn(self):
1114        """
1115        Synonym for to_Equation.
1116        Return: recasts the Equality as an Equation.
1117        """
1118        return self.to_Equation()
1119
1120Eq = Equality
1121
1122def __FiniteSet__repr__override__(self):
1123    """Override of the `FiniteSet.__repr__(self)` to overcome sympy's
1124    inconsistent wrapping of Finite Sets which prevents reliable use of
1125    copy and paste of the code representation.
1126    """
1127    insidestr = ""
1128    for k in self.args:
1129        insidestr += k.__repr__() +', '
1130    insidestr = insidestr[:-2]
1131    reprstr = "FiniteSet("+ insidestr + ")"
1132    return reprstr
1133
1134sympy.sets.FiniteSet.__repr__ = __FiniteSet__repr__override__
1135
1136def __FiniteSet__str__override__(self):
1137    """Override of the `FiniteSet.__str__(self)` to overcome sympy's
1138    inconsistent wrapping of Finite Sets which prevents reliable use of
1139    copy and paste of the code representation.
1140    """
1141    insidestr = ""
1142    for k in self.args:
1143        insidestr += str(k) + ', '
1144    insidestr = insidestr[:-2]
1145    strrep = "{"+ insidestr + "}"
1146    return strrep
1147
1148sympy.sets.FiniteSet.__str__ = __FiniteSet__str__override__
1149
1150#####
1151# Extension of the Function class. For incorporation into SymPy this should
1152# become part of the class
1153#####
1154class EqnFunction(Function):
1155    """
1156    Extension of the sympy Function class to understand equations. Each
1157    sympy function impacted by this extension is listed in the documentation
1158    that follows.
1159    """
1160    def __new__(cls, *args, **kwargs):
1161        n = len(args)
1162        eqnloc = None
1163        neqns = 0
1164        newargs = []
1165        for k in args:
1166            newargs.append(k)
1167        if (n > 0):
1168            for i in range(n):
1169                if isinstance(args[i], Equation):
1170                    neqns += 1
1171                    eqnloc = i
1172            if neqns > 1:
1173                raise NotImplementedError('Function calls with more than one '
1174                                          'Equation as a parameter are not '
1175                                          'supported. You may be able to get '
1176                                          'your desired outcome using .applyrhs'
1177                                          ' and .applylhs.')
1178            if neqns == 1:
1179                newargs[eqnloc] = args[eqnloc].lhs
1180                lhs = super().__new__(cls, *newargs, **kwargs)
1181                newargs[eqnloc] = args[eqnloc].rhs
1182                rhs = super().__new__(cls, *newargs, **kwargs)
1183                return Equation(lhs,rhs)
1184        return super().__new__(cls, *args, **kwargs)
1185
1186def str_to_extend_sympy_func(func:str):
1187    """
1188    Generates the string command to execute for a sympy function to
1189    gain the properties of the extended EqnFunction class.
1190    """
1191    execstr = 'class ' + str(func) + '(' + str(
1192        func) + ',EqnFunction):\n    ' \
1193                'pass\n'
1194    return execstr
1195
1196# TODO: Below will not be needed when incorporated into SymPy.
1197# This is hacky, but I have not been able to come up with another way
1198# of extending the functions programmatically, if this is separate package
1199# from sympy that extends it after loading sympy.
1200#  Functions listed in `skip` are not applicable to equations or cannot be
1201#  extended because of `mro` error or `metaclass conflict`. This reflects
1202#  that some of these are not members of the Sympy Function class.
1203
1204# Overridden elsewhere
1205_extended_ = ('sqrt', 'root', 'Heaviside')
1206
1207# Either not applicable to equations or have not yet figured out a way
1208# to systematically apply to an equation.
1209# TODO examine these more carefully (top priority: real_root, cbrt, Ynm_c).
1210_not_applicable_to_equations_ = ('Min', 'Max', 'Id', 'real_root', 'cbrt',
1211        'unbranched_argument', 'polarify', 'unpolarify',
1212        'piecewise_fold', 'E1', 'Eijk', 'bspline_basis',
1213        'bspline_basis_set', 'interpolating_spline', 'jn_zeros',
1214        'jacobi_normalized', 'Ynm_c', 'piecewise_exclusive', 'Piecewise',
1215        'motzkin', 'hyper','meijerg', 'chebyshevu_root', 'chebyshevt_root',
1216        'betainc_regularized')
1217_skip_ = _extended_ + _not_applicable_to_equations_
1218
1219for func in functions.__all__:
1220
1221    if func not in _skip_:
1222        try:
1223            exec(str_to_extend_sympy_func(func), globals(), locals())
1224        except TypeError:
1225            from warnings import warn
1226            warn('SymPy function/operation ' + str(func) + ' may not work ' \
1227                'properly with Equations. If you use it with Equations, ' \
1228                'validate its behavior. We are working to address this ' \
1229                'issue.')
1230
1231# Redirect python abs() to Abs()
1232abs = Abs
class algwsym_config: 
 40class algwsym_config():
 41
 42    def __init__(self):
 43        """
 44        This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of
 45        the algebra_with_sympy package.
 46
 47        Settings
 48        ========
 49        Printing
 50        --------
 51        In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a
 52        human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals
 53        sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign.
 54        `print(Eqn)` or `str(Eqn)` will return this human readable text version of
 55        the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not
 56        sympy, where `str()` is supposed to return something that can be
 57        copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in `eq1 =
 58        Eqn(a,b/c)` the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in
 59        parentheses (eg. `a = b/c    (eq1)`). Use `print(repr(Eqn))` instead of
 60        `print(Eqn)` or `repr(Eqn)` instead of `str(Eqn)` to get a code
 61        compatible version of the equation.
 62
 63        You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:
 64        * `algwsym_config.output.show_code` default is `False`.
 65        * `algwsym_config.output.human_text` default is `True`.
 66        * `algwsym_config.output.label` default is `True`.
 67
 68        In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting
 69        the `algwsym_config.output.show_code` flag. If this flag is true
 70        calls to `latex` and `str` will also print an additional line "code
 71        version: `repr(Eqn)`". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset
 72        mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted.
 73        Default is `False`.
 74
 75        A second flag `algwsym_config.output.human_text` is useful in
 76        text-based interactive environments such as command line python or
 77        ipython. If this flag is true `repr` will return `str`. Thus the human
 78        readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an
 79        expression containing an equation.
 80        Default is `True`.
 81
 82        Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython
 83        environment will show both the code version and the human readable text.
 84        These flags impact the behavior of the `print(Eqn)` statement.
 85
 86        The third flag `algwsym_config.output.label` has a default value of
 87        `True`. Setting this to `False` suppresses the labeling of an equation
 88        with its python name off to the right of the equation.
 89        """
 90        pass
 91
 92    class output():
 93
 94        def __init__(self):
 95            """This holds settings that impact output.
 96            """
 97            pass
 98
 99        @property
100        def show_code(self):
101            """
102            If `True` code versions of the equation expression will be
103            output in interactive environments. Default = `False`.
104            """
105            return self.show_code
106
107        @property
108        def human_text(self):
109            """
110            If `True` the human readable equation expression will be
111            output in text interactive environments. Default = `False`.
112            """
113            return self.human_text
114
115        @property
116        def solve_to_list(self):
117            """
118            If `True` the results of a call to `solve(...)` will return a
119            Python `list` rather than a Sympy `FiniteSet`. This recovers
120            behavior for versions before 0.11.0.
121
122            Note: setting this `True` means that expressions within the
123            returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and
124            IPython.
125            """
126            return self.solve_to_list
algwsym_config() 
42    def __init__(self):
43        """
44        This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of
45        the algebra_with_sympy package.
46
47        Settings
48        ========
49        Printing
50        --------
51        In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a
52        human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals
53        sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign.
54        `print(Eqn)` or `str(Eqn)` will return this human readable text version of
55        the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not
56        sympy, where `str()` is supposed to return something that can be
57        copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in `eq1 =
58        Eqn(a,b/c)` the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in
59        parentheses (eg. `a = b/c    (eq1)`). Use `print(repr(Eqn))` instead of
60        `print(Eqn)` or `repr(Eqn)` instead of `str(Eqn)` to get a code
61        compatible version of the equation.
62
63        You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:
64        * `algwsym_config.output.show_code` default is `False`.
65        * `algwsym_config.output.human_text` default is `True`.
66        * `algwsym_config.output.label` default is `True`.
67
68        In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting
69        the `algwsym_config.output.show_code` flag. If this flag is true
70        calls to `latex` and `str` will also print an additional line "code
71        version: `repr(Eqn)`". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset
72        mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted.
73        Default is `False`.
74
75        A second flag `algwsym_config.output.human_text` is useful in
76        text-based interactive environments such as command line python or
77        ipython. If this flag is true `repr` will return `str`. Thus the human
78        readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an
79        expression containing an equation.
80        Default is `True`.
81
82        Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython
83        environment will show both the code version and the human readable text.
84        These flags impact the behavior of the `print(Eqn)` statement.
85
86        The third flag `algwsym_config.output.label` has a default value of
87        `True`. Setting this to `False` suppresses the labeling of an equation
88        with its python name off to the right of the equation.
89        """
90        pass

This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of the algebra_with_sympy package.

Settings

Printing

In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign. print(Eqn) or str(Eqn) will return this human readable text version of the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not sympy, where str() is supposed to return something that can be copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in eq1 = Eqn(a,b/c) the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in parentheses (eg. a = b/c (eq1)). Use print(repr(Eqn)) instead of print(Eqn) or repr(Eqn) instead of str(Eqn) to get a code compatible version of the equation.

You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:

  • algwsym_config.output.show_code default is False.
  • algwsym_config.output.human_text default is True.
  • algwsym_config.output.label default is True.

In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting the algwsym_config.output.show_code flag. If this flag is true calls to latex and str will also print an additional line "code version: repr(Eqn)". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted. Default is False.

A second flag algwsym_config.output.human_text is useful in text-based interactive environments such as command line python or ipython. If this flag is true repr will return str. Thus the human readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an expression containing an equation. Default is True.

Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython environment will show both the code version and the human readable text. These flags impact the behavior of the print(Eqn) statement.

The third flag algwsym_config.output.label has a default value of True. Setting this to False suppresses the labeling of an equation with its python name off to the right of the equation.

class algwsym_config.output: 
 92    class output():
 93
 94        def __init__(self):
 95            """This holds settings that impact output.
 96            """
 97            pass
 98
 99        @property
100        def show_code(self):
101            """
102            If `True` code versions of the equation expression will be
103            output in interactive environments. Default = `False`.
104            """
105            return self.show_code
106
107        @property
108        def human_text(self):
109            """
110            If `True` the human readable equation expression will be
111            output in text interactive environments. Default = `False`.
112            """
113            return self.human_text
114
115        @property
116        def solve_to_list(self):
117            """
118            If `True` the results of a call to `solve(...)` will return a
119            Python `list` rather than a Sympy `FiniteSet`. This recovers
120            behavior for versions before 0.11.0.
121
122            Note: setting this `True` means that expressions within the
123            returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and
124            IPython.
125            """
126            return self.solve_to_list
algwsym_config.output() 
94        def __init__(self):
95            """This holds settings that impact output.
96            """
97            pass

This holds settings that impact output.

show_code = False

If True code versions of the equation expression will be output in interactive environments. Default = False.

human_text = True

If True the human readable equation expression will be output in text interactive environments. Default = False.

solve_to_list = False

If True the results of a call to solve(...) will return a Python list rather than a Sympy FiniteSet. This recovers behavior for versions before 0.11.0.

Note: setting this True means that expressions within the returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and IPython.

class Equation(sympy.core.basic.Basic, sympy.core.evalf.EvalfMixin): 
184class Equation(Basic, EvalfMixin):
185    """
186    This class defines an equation with a left-hand-side (tlhs) and a right-
187    hand-side (rhs) connected by the "=" operator (e.g. `p*V = n*R*T`).
188
189    Explanation
190    ===========
191    This class defines relations that all high school and college students
192    would recognize as mathematical equations. At present only the "=" relation
193    operator is recognized.
194
195    This class is intended to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to
196    rearrange equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this
197    way more people can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without
198    stumbling over missed details such as a negative sign.
199
200    Create an equation with the call ``Equation(lhs,rhs)``, where ``lhs`` and
201    ``rhs`` are any valid Sympy expression. ``Eqn(...)`` is a synonym for
202    ``Equation(...)``.
203
204    Parameters
205    ==========
206    lhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
207    rhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
208    kwargs:
209
210    Examples
211    ========
212    NOTE: All the examples below are in vanilla python. You can get human
213    readable eqautions "lhs = rhs" in vanilla python by adjusting the settings
214    in `algwsym_config` (see it's documentation). Output is human readable by
215    default in IPython and Jupyter environments.
216    >>> from algebra_with_sympy import *
217    >>> a, b, c, x = var('a b c x')
218    >>> Equation(a,b/c)
219    Equation(a, b/c)
220    >>> t=Eqn(a,b/c)
221    >>> t
222    Equation(a, b/c)
223    >>> t*c
224    Equation(a*c, b)
225    >>> c*t
226    Equation(a*c, b)
227    >>> exp(t)
228    Equation(exp(a), exp(b/c))
229    >>> exp(log(t))
230    Equation(a, b/c)
231
232    Simplification and Expansion
233    >>> f = Eqn(x**2 - 1, c)
234    >>> f
235    Equation(x**2 - 1, c)
236    >>> f/(x+1)
237    Equation((x**2 - 1)/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
238    >>> (f/(x+1)).simplify()
239    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
240    >>> simplify(f/(x+1))
241    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
242    >>> (f/(x+1)).expand()
243    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
244    >>> expand(f/(x+1))
245    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
246    >>> factor(f)
247    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
248    >>> f.factor()
249    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
250    >>> f2 = f+a*x**2+b*x +c
251    >>> f2
252    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c + x**2 - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
253    >>> collect(f2,x)
254    Equation(b*x + c + x**2*(a + 1) - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
255
256    Apply operation to only one side
257    >>> poly = Eqn(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
258    >>> poly.applyrhs(factor,x)
259    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(c + x**2*(a + b)))
260    >>> poly.applylhs(factor)
261    Equation(x*(a*x + b + c*x), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
262    >>> poly.applylhs(collect,x)
263    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
264
265    ``.apply...`` also works with user defined python functions
266    >>> def addsquare(eqn):
267    ...     return eqn+eqn**2
268    ...
269    >>> t.apply(addsquare)
270    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
271    >>> t.applyrhs(addsquare)
272    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
273    >>> t.apply(addsquare, side = 'rhs')
274    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
275    >>> t.applylhs(addsquare)
276    Equation(a**2 + a, b/c)
277    >>> addsquare(t)
278    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
279
280    Inaddition to ``.apply...`` there is also the less general ``.do``,
281    ``.dolhs``, ``.dorhs``, which only works for operations defined on the
282    ``Expr`` class (e.g.``.collect(), .factor(), .expand()``, etc...).
283    >>> poly.dolhs.collect(x)
284    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
285    >>> poly.dorhs.collect(x)
286    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, c*x + x**3*(a + b))
287    >>> poly.do.collect(x)
288    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), c*x + x**3*(a + b))
289    >>> poly.dorhs.factor()
290    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(a*x**2 + b*x**2 + c))
291
292    ``poly.do.exp()`` or other sympy math functions will raise an error.
293
294    Rearranging an equation (simple example made complicated as illustration)
295    >>> p, V, n, R, T = var('p V n R T')
296    >>> eq1=Eqn(p*V,n*R*T)
297    >>> eq1
298    Equation(V*p, R*T*n)
299    >>> eq2 =eq1/V
300    >>> eq2
301    Equation(p, R*T*n/V)
302    >>> eq3 = eq2/R/T
303    >>> eq3
304    Equation(p/(R*T), n/V)
305    >>> eq4 = eq3*R/p
306    >>> eq4
307    Equation(1/T, R*n/(V*p))
308    >>> 1/eq4
309    Equation(T, V*p/(R*n))
310    >>> eq5 = 1/eq4 - T
311    >>> eq5
312    Equation(0, -T + V*p/(R*n))
313
314    Substitution (#'s and units)
315    >>> L, atm, mol, K = var('L atm mol K', positive=True, real=True) # units
316    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L})
317    Equation(p, 0.9334325*atm)
318    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L}).evalf(4)
319    Equation(p, 0.9334*atm)
320
321    Substituting an equation into another equation:
322    >>> P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2 = symbols("P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2")
323    >>> eq1 = Eqn(P, P1 + P2)
324    >>> eq2 = Eqn(P1 / (A1 * E1), P2 / (A2 * E2))
325    >>> P1_val = (eq1 - P2).swap
326    >>> P1_val
327    Equation(P1, P - P2)
328    >>> eq2 = eq2.subs(P1_val)
329    >>> eq2
330    Equation((P - P2)/(A1*E1), P2/(A2*E2))
331    >>> P2_val = solve(eq2.subs(P1_val), P2).args[0]
332    >>> P2_val
333    Equation(P2, A2*E2*P/(A1*E1 + A2*E2))
334
335    Combining equations (Math with equations: lhs with lhs and rhs with rhs)
336    >>> q = Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
337    >>> q
338    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
339    >>> t
340    Equation(a, b/c)
341    >>> q+t
342    Equation(a*c + a, b/c + b/c**2)
343    >>> q/t
344    Equation(c, 1/c)
345    >>> t**q
346    Equation(a**(a*c), (b/c)**(b/c**2))
347
348    Utility operations
349    >>> t.reversed
350    Equation(b/c, a)
351    >>> t.swap
352    Equation(b/c, a)
353    >>> t.lhs
354    a
355    >>> t.rhs
356    b/c
357    >>> t.as_Boolean()
358    Eq(a, b/c)
359
360    `.check()` convenience method for `.as_Boolean().simplify()`
361    >>> from sympy import I, pi
362    >>> Equation(pi*(I+2), pi*I+2*pi).check()
363    True
364    >>> Eqn(a,a+1).check()
365    False
366
367    Differentiation
368    Differentiation is applied to both sides if the wrt variable appears on
369    both sides.
370    >>> q=Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
371    >>> q
372    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
373    >>> diff(q,b)
374    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b), c**(-2))
375    >>> diff(q,c)
376    Equation(a, -2*b/c**3)
377    >>> diff(log(q),b)
378    Equation(Derivative(log(a*c), b), 1/b)
379    >>> diff(q,c,2)
380    Equation(Derivative(a, c), 6*b/c**4)
381
382    If you specify multiple differentiation all at once the assumption
383    is order of differentiation matters and the lhs will not be
384    evaluated.
385    >>> diff(q,c,b)
386    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
387
388    To overcome this specify the order of operations.
389    >>> diff(diff(q,c),b)
390    Equation(Derivative(a, b), -2/c**3)
391
392    But the reverse order returns an unevaulated lhs (a may depend on b).
393    >>> diff(diff(q,b),c)
394    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
395
396    Integration can only be performed on one side at a time.
397    >>> q=Eqn(a*c,b/c)
398    >>> integrate(q,b,side='rhs')
399    b**2/(2*c)
400    >>> integrate(q,b,side='lhs')
401    a*b*c
402
403    Make a pretty statement of integration from an equation
404    >>> Eqn(Integral(q.lhs,b),integrate(q,b,side='rhs'))
405    Equation(Integral(a*c, b), b**2/(2*c))
406
407    Integration of each side with respect to different variables
408    >>> q.dorhs.integrate(b).dolhs.integrate(a)
409    Equation(a**2*c/2, b**2/(2*c))
410
411    Automatic solutions using sympy solvers. THIS IS EXPERIMENTAL. Please
412    report issues at https://github.com/gutow/Algebra_with_Sympy/issues.
413    >>> tosolv = Eqn(a - b, c/a)
414    >>> solve(tosolv,a)
415    FiniteSet(Equation(a, b/2 - sqrt(b**2 + 4*c)/2), Equation(a, b/2 + sqrt(b**2 + 4*c)/2))
416    >>> solve(tosolv, b)
417    FiniteSet(Equation(b, (a**2 - c)/a))
418    >>> solve(tosolv, c)
419    FiniteSet(Equation(c, a**2 - a*b))
420    """
421
422    def __new__(cls, lhs, rhs, **kwargs):
423        lhs = _sympify(lhs)
424        rhs = _sympify(rhs)
425        if not isinstance(lhs, Expr) or not isinstance(rhs, Expr):
426            raise TypeError('lhs and rhs must be valid sympy expressions.')
427        return super().__new__(cls, lhs, rhs)
428
429    def _get_eqn_name(self):
430        """
431        Tries to find the python string name that refers to the equation. In
432        IPython environments (IPython, Jupyter, etc...) looks in the user_ns.
433        If not in an IPython environment looks in __main__.
434        :return: string value if found or empty string.
435        """
436        human_text = algwsym_config.output.human_text
437        algwsym_config.output.human_text=False
438        import __main__ as shell
439        for k in dir(shell):
440            item = getattr(shell,k)
441            if isinstance(item,Equation):
442                if item.__repr__()==self.__repr__() and not \
443                        k.startswith('_'):
444                    algwsym_config.output.human_text=human_text
445                    return k
446        algwsym_config.output.human_text = human_text
447        return ''
448
449    @property
450    def lhs(self):
451        """
452        Returns the lhs of the equation.
453        """
454        return self.args[0]
455
456    @property
457    def rhs(self):
458        """
459        Returns the rhs of the equation.
460        """
461        return self.args[1]
462
463    def as_Boolean(self):
464        """
465        Converts the equation to an Equality.
466        """
467        return Equality(self.lhs, self.rhs)
468
469    def check(self, **kwargs):
470        """
471        Forces simplification and casts as `Equality` to check validity.
472        Parameters
473        ----------
474        kwargs any appropriate for `Equality`.
475
476        Returns
477        -------
478        True, False or an unevaluated `Equality` if truth cannot be determined.
479        """
480        return Equality(self.lhs, self.rhs, **kwargs).simplify()
481
482    @property
483    def reversed(self):
484        """
485        Swaps the lhs and the rhs.
486        """
487        return Equation(self.rhs, self.lhs)
488
489    @property
490    def swap(self):
491        """
492        Synonym for `.reversed`
493        """
494        return self.reversed
495
496    def _applytoexpr(self, expr, func, *args, **kwargs):
497        # Applies a function to an expression checking whether there
498        # is a specialized version associated with the particular type of
499        # expression. Errors will be raised if the function cannot be
500        # applied to an expression.
501        funcname = getattr(func, '__name__', None)
502        if funcname is not None:
503            localfunc = getattr(expr, funcname, None)
504            if localfunc is not None:
505                return localfunc(*args, **kwargs)
506        return func(expr, *args, **kwargs)
507
508    def apply(self, func, *args, side='both', **kwargs):
509        """
510        Apply an operation/function/method to the equation returning the
511        resulting equation.
512
513        Parameters
514        ==========
515
516        func: object
517            object to apply usually a function
518
519        args: as necessary for the function
520
521        side: 'both', 'lhs', 'rhs', optional
522            Specifies which side of the equation the operation will be applied
523            to. Default is 'both'.
524
525        kwargs: as necessary for the function
526         """
527        lhs = self.lhs
528        rhs = self.rhs
529        if side in ('both', 'lhs'):
530            lhs = self._applytoexpr(self.lhs, func, *args, **kwargs)
531        if side in ('both', 'rhs'):
532            rhs = self._applytoexpr(self.rhs, func, *args, **kwargs)
533        return Equation(lhs, rhs)
534
535    def applylhs(self, func, *args, **kwargs):
536        """
537        If lhs side of the equation has a defined subfunction (attribute) of
538        name ``func``, that will be applied instead of the global function.
539        The operation is applied to only the lhs.
540        """
541        return self.apply(func, *args, **kwargs, side='lhs')
542
543    def applyrhs(self, func, *args, **kwargs):
544        """
545        If rhs side of the equation has a defined subfunction (attribute) of
546        name ``func``, that will be applied instead of the global function.
547        The operation is applied to only the rhs.
548        """
549        return self.apply(func, *args, **kwargs, side='rhs')
550
551    class _sides:
552        """
553        Helper class for the `.do.`, `.dolhs.`, `.dorhs.` syntax for applying
554        submethods of expressions.
555        """
556
557        def __init__(self, eqn, side='both'):
558            self.eqn = eqn
559            self.side = side
560
561        def __getattr__(self, name):
562            func = None
563            if self.side in ('rhs', 'both'):
564                func = getattr(self.eqn.rhs, name, None)
565            else:
566                func = getattr(self.eqn.lhs, name, None)
567            if func is None:
568                raise AttributeError('Expressions in the equation have no '
569                                     'attribute `' + str(
570                    name) + '`. Try `.apply('
571                                     + str(name) + ', *args)` or '
572                                                   'pass the equation as a parameter to `'
573                                     + str(name) + '()`.')
574            return functools.partial(self.eqn.apply, func, side=self.side)
575
576    @property
577    def do(self):
578        return self._sides(self, side='both')
579
580    @property
581    def dolhs(self):
582        return self._sides(self, side='lhs')
583
584    @property
585    def dorhs(self):
586        return self._sides(self, side='rhs')
587    
588    def _eval_rewrite(self, rule, args, **kwargs):
589        """Return Equation(L, R) as Equation(L - R, 0) or as L - R.
590
591        Parameters
592        ==========
593
594        evaluate : bool, optional
595            Control the evaluation of the result. If `evaluate=None` then
596            terms in L and R will not cancel but they will be listed in
597            canonical order; otherwise non-canonical args will be returned.
598            Default to True.
599        
600        eqn : bool, optional
601            Control the returned type. If `eqn=True`, then Equation(L - R, 0)
602            is returned. Otherwise, the L - R symbolic expression is returned.
603            Default to True.
604
605        Examples
606        ========
607        >>> from sympy import Add
608        >>> from sympy.abc import b, x
609        >>> from algebra_with_sympy import Equation
610        >>> eq = Equation(x + b, x - b)
611        >>> eq.rewrite(Add)
612        Equation(2*b, 0)
613        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, evaluate=None).lhs.args
614        (b, b, x, -x)
615        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, evaluate=False).lhs.args
616        (b, x, b, -x)
617        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, eqn=False)
618        2*b
619        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, eqn=False, evaluate=False).args
620        (b, x, b, -x)
621        """
622        if rule == Add:
623            # NOTE: the code about `evaluate` is very similar to
624            # sympy.core.relational.Equality._eval_rewrite_as_Add
625            eqn = kwargs.pop("eqn", True)
626            evaluate = kwargs.get('evaluate', True)
627            L, R = args
628            if evaluate:
629                # allow cancellation of args
630                expr = L - R
631            else:
632                args = Add.make_args(L) + Add.make_args(-R)
633                if evaluate is None:
634                    # no cancellation, but canonical
635                    expr = _unevaluated_Add(*args)
636                else:
637                    # no cancellation, not canonical
638                    expr = Add._from_args(args)
639            if eqn:
640                return self.func(expr, 0)
641            return expr
642
643    def subs(self, *args, **kwargs):
644        """Substitutes old for new in an equation after sympifying args.
645    
646        `args` is either:
647
648        * one or more arguments of type `Equation(old, new)`.
649        * two arguments, e.g. foo.subs(old, new)
650        * one iterable argument, e.g. foo.subs(iterable). The iterable may be:
651
652            - an iterable container with (old, new) pairs. In this case the
653              replacements are processed in the order given with successive
654              patterns possibly affecting replacements already made.
655            - a dict or set whose key/value items correspond to old/new pairs.
656              In this case the old/new pairs will be sorted by op count and in
657              case of a tie, by number of args and the default_sort_key. The
658              resulting sorted list is then processed as an iterable container
659              (see previous).
660        
661        If the keyword ``simultaneous`` is True, the subexpressions will not be
662        evaluated until all the substitutions have been made.
663
664        Please, read ``help(Expr.subs)`` for more examples.
665
666        Examples
667        ========
668
669        >>> from sympy.abc import a, b, c, x
670        >>> from algebra_with_sympy import Equation
671        >>> eq = Equation(x + a, b * c)
672
673        Substitute a single value:
674
675        >>> eq.subs(b, 4)
676        Equation(a + x, 4*c)
677
678        Substitute a multiple values:
679
680        >>> eq.subs([(a, 2), (b, 4)])
681        Equation(x + 2, 4*c)
682        >>> eq.subs({a: 2, b: 4})
683        Equation(x + 2, 4*c)
684
685        Substitute an equation into another equation:
686
